Dialogue: No, no trouble, Harry, be right down.  Son of a bitch.

Dialogue: OK.

Dialogue: Mr. Rafferty has that position. Whatever you want, you'll have to get from him, I have nothing more to say.

Dialogue: Look, I told you inside--

Dialogue: --you have nothing more to say, I understand that.

Dialogue: I assure you, there's nothing mysterious involved.

Dialogue: So?

Dialogue: Did you know to come because one of the other men involved in the break- in called you?

Dialogue: There is no reason to assume other people were involved.

Dialogue: Your clients were arrested with a walkie-talkie; they didn't need that to talk among themselves.

Dialogue: They are not my clients.

Dialogue: You're a lawyer and you're here--

Dialogue: --I met one of the defendants, Mr. Barker, at a social occasion once--  --I have nothing more to say.

Dialogue: Mr. Rafferty told me the Cubans were from Miami.

Dialogue: It was really nice of you to come, since you'd only met him once.

Dialogue: Are you implying you don't believe me?

Dialogue: I have nothing more to say.

Dialogue: You don't mind getting on people's nerves, do you?

Dialogue: Nope.

Dialogue: Your name, please.

Dialogue: James McCord.

Dialogue: Will you step forward, sir.

Dialogue: And what is your occupation, Mr. McCord?

Dialogue: Where?

Dialogue: ...Central... Intelligence... Agency...

Dialogue: Where?

Dialogue: Holy shit.

Dialogue: Bachinski?  --OK, go on, go on...

Dialogue: ...go on, go on...

Dialogue: Could develop.

Dialogue: I did all right on McCord.

Dialogue: You can't believe that.

Dialogue: What'd you get on W.House?

Dialogue: Lotsa hints--

Dialogue: Call someone you don't know.

Dialogue: Thanks, anyway--

Dialogue: Howard Hunt, please.

Dialogue: Thanks, anyway.

Dialogue: So?

Dialogue: That was fun.  What now?

Dialogue: And you haven't called him?--

Dialogue: You asking me to disclose my source?

Dialogue: Get some harder information next time.

Dialogue: Nothing, that's the problem--the story's gone underground.

Dialogue: You thought I'd help out on specifics?  How much?

Dialogue: I don't know maybe sixteen, eighteen hours a day--we've got sources at Justice, the FBI, but it's still drying up.

Dialogue: If you don't like them, why won't you be more concrete with me?

Dialogue: Because the press stinks too--history on the run, that's all you're interested in.  You come up with anything?

Dialogue: John Mitchell resigned as head of CREEP to spend more time with his family. That doesn't exactly have the ring of truth.  Howard Hunt's been found--there was talk that his lawyer had 25 thousand in cash in a paper bag.

Dialogue: Follow the money. Always follow the money.

Dialogue: To where?

Dialogue: Go on.

Dialogue: You changed cabs? You're sure no one followed you?

Dialogue: I did everything you said, but it all seemed--

Dialogue: --melodramatic?  Things are past that--remember, these are men with switchblade mentalities who run the world as if it were Dodge City.

Dialogue: What's the whole thing about--do you know?

Dialogue: What I know, you'll have to find out on your own.

Dialogue: Liddy--you think there's a chance he'll talk?

Dialogue: What's that?

Dialogue: Goddamnit--

Dialogue: --I'm trying--

Dialogue: Why didn't we get that?

Dialogue: Christ, and I even know somebody at the phone company--

Dialogue: --you do?--with access to records?

Dialogue: Why couldn't you have just dialed me from the office, Irwin?

Dialogue: So tell me about the Times article.

Dialogue: What do you want to know?

Dialogue: No games, Irwin; give.

Dialogue: What're you onto?

Dialogue: Something maybe big.

Dialogue: And that makes anything you do OK, is that it?

Dialogue: Just tell me about the goddamn article.

Dialogue: Who by?

Dialogue: Irwin? I really feel bad, doing something like this--you know that, don't you?

Dialogue: Don't give me any more of your liberal shit, OK, Carl?

Dialogue: Howard--

Dialogue: --nobody gives a shit about the Dahlberg repercussions--

Speaker: rosenfeld
Dialogue: --our story got Government Accounting to start an audit on CREEP's finances--

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: --and we printed that, didn't we, Harry? And when the frigging audit's done, we'll print that too--

Speaker: national editor
Dialogue: --let me tell what happened when I was having lunch today at the Sans Souci--

Speaker: rosenfeld
Dialogue: --correction--when you were drinking your lunch at the bar of the Sans Souci--

Speaker: national editor
Dialogue: --this White House guy, a good one, a pro, came up and asked what is this Watergate compulsion with you guys and I said, well, we think it's important and he said, if it's so goddamn important, who the hell are Woodward and Bernstein?

Speaker: rosenfeld
Dialogue: Ask him what he's really saying--he means take the story away from Woodstein and give it to his people at the National Desk--

Speaker: national editor
Dialogue: --well, I've got some pretty experienced fellas sitting around, wouldn't you say so?--

Speaker: rosenfeld
Dialogue: --absolutely--and that's all they do, sit sit sit--every once in a while, they call up a Senator, some reporting--

Speaker: national editor
Dialogue: --well, what if your boys get it wrong--

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: Then it's our asses, isn't it?

Speaker: simons
Dialogue: And we'll all have to go to work for a living.

Speaker: foreign editor
Dialogue: I don't think either Metropolitan or National should cover the story.  I don't think we should cover the story, period.

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: Go on.

Speaker: foreign editor
Dialogue: It's not that we're using unnamed sources that bothers me, or that everything we print the White House denies, or that almost no other papers are reprinting our stuff.

Speaker: simons
Dialogue: What then?

Speaker: foreign editor
Dialogue: I don't believe the goddamn story, Howard, it doesn't make sense.

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: It will, it just hasn't bottomed out yet, give it time.

Speaker: foreign editor
Dialogue: Ben, Jesus, there are over two thousand reporters in this town, are there five on Watergate? Where did we suddenly get all this wisdom?

Speaker: foreign editor
Dialogue: Look--why would the Republicans do it? --my God, McGovern is self- destructing before our eyes--just like Muskie did, Humphrey, the bunch of 'em.  Why would the burglars have put the tape around the door instead of up and down unless they wanted to get caught? Why did they take a walkie- talkie and then turn it off, unless they wanted to get caught? Why would they use McCord--the only direct contact to the Republicans?

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: You saying the Democrats bugged themselves?

Speaker: foreign editor
Dialogue: The FBI thinks it's possible--the Democrats need a campaign issue, corruption's always a good one.  Get off the story, Ben--or put some people on McGovern's finances; fair is fair, even in our business.

Speaker: union guy
Dialogue: What'd'ya think?

Speaker: union guy
Dialogue: Big fuckin' cookie jar.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: This is practically a high school reunion for us, Jane--I would have sprung for a classier place.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Anyplace really public, they'd know about it--they know everything at the Committee, Carl--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --you don't really think you're being followed?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: This girlfriend of mine at the Committee, the other day she went back to the D.A. to tell the things the FBI didn't ask her. That night, her boss, he knew what she'd done. They control everything; that's how they know it all.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: FBI too?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You don't believe me? Well, I was working the weekend of the break-in and my God, all the executives were running around like crazy--you had to practically wait in line to use the shredding machine--and when the FBI came to investigate, they never even asked me about it.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: If you don't like it down there, why don't you quit?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I don't know what they'd do to me.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Hey, easy...

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: ...and I'm scared.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: I can help if you'll--

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: We have no one by the name of Mitchell registered.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: My mistake, sorry.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Get me John Mitchell, it's urgent.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Can I speak to Martha Mitchell, please.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: I've met Mrs. Mitchell in Washington, I'm Bob Woodward of the Post and tell her--

Speaker: first maid
Dialogue: We'll be back after lunch.

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: We'll be here.

Speaker: second maid
Dialogue: I think they went out.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: I don't mind waiting.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Get anything?

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: For the paper, no; for us, plenty.  I waited a long time and finally this big guy--I guess a bodyguard-- he left and I knocked and she remembered me, we talked awhile.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: And?--And?--

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: --she was panicked, Carl--every time I mentioned Watergate, you could tell.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Were you eyebrow reading?

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: It was there. I just don't get it; a CREEP secretary being scared, that's one thing. But what does the wife of one of the most powerful men in America have to be afraid of...?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Left up ahead.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Who's first?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Alphabetically, on the CREEP phone list, Miss Helen Abbott of South George Street.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Now hang your second right--  --this was my turf when I was a kid.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: I don't get it... this really was my turf...

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: You're not a kid anymore.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Just wanted you to know I've done dumber things than get us lost, that's all.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Hi. I'm Bob Woodward of the Washington Post and I hate to bother you at home--

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: No, I'm a reporter. I wanted to talk to you about the Committee to Re- Elect.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: You work there, Miss Abbott.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Miss Abbott?

Speaker: miss abbott
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: We're from the Washington Post and we wanted to ask you some questions about the Committee.

Speaker: miss abbott
Dialogue: I'm sorry--

Speaker: old man
Dialogue: --go--you've got to go before they see you--please--

Speaker: old woman
Dialogue: --no... good...

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: You had the Mighty Mo and the fries without gravy, right?

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: This is terrific work, if you like rejection.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: I never scared anyone before.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: It's not us, they were scared before we got there.  What do we know?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Facts or theory?

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Anything you've got.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: We know there's got to be something or they wouldn't be so panicked.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: And that something's got to be more than just Hunt, Liddy, and the five burglars--those indictments are gonna be bullshit when they come down. What else do we know?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: I just wish we knew when someone would talk to us, that's all.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: A friend at the Committee told us to contact you--

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: --who was it?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: We never reveal our sources, which is why you can talk to us.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: It's safe, try it, you'll see.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: We understand your problem--

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: --you believe in the President, you wouldn't ever want to do anything disloyal.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: We appreciate your position--really.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: You people--you think that you can come into someone's life, squeeze what you want, then get out.  --do you like scaring the life out of decent people?--'cause if you don't, in the name of God--stop it!

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: At Yale once, they held an auction. There was this woman and her name was Lulu Landis. Her postcards came up for sale. She had 1400 postcards written to her and I'd never heard of her before but I knew I had to have those cards, I had to know why anyone would get so many messages. I paid sixty-five dollars for them... I got all crazy trying to work it out and first it was just a maze but then I found that her husband killed himself in Dayton, and once I had that, it all began to open, an evangelist had come to Dayton and his horses hit Lulu Landis at the corner of 13th and Vermillion and she was paralyzed. Permanently, and her favorite thing til then had been traveling and all her friends, whenever they went anyplace, they wrote her. Those cards, they were her eyes...

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Democrats?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: I hate both parties.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: And I'm a Republican.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Republican?

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Who'd you vote for?

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Nixon.

Speaker: younger man
Dialogue: --oh, don't worry, Gordon Liddy will be happy to take the fall for everyone because, well, it's not that Gordon's crazy, he's...  ...weird. I'll give you some Committee people who know about him--only don't tell it was me--

Speaker: younger woman
Dialogue: --of course we were briefed on what to say--and never to volunteer anything--

Speaker: old woman
Dialogue: --oh, we were never alone with the FBI, there was always someone from the Committee right there--

Speaker: nixon
Dialogue: ...No one in this administration, presently employed, was involved in this very bizarre incident...

Speaker: nixon
Dialogue: ...What really hurts in matters of this sort is not the fact that they occur, because overzealous people in campaigns do things that are wrong. What really hurts is if you try to cover it up.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Did he just say what I think he said?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: You voted for him.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Hi, I'm Carl Bernstein of the Washington Post and--

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: --oh, you don't want me, you want my sister.  For you.

Speaker: bookkeeper's sister
Dialogue: This here is Carl Bernstein--

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: --omigod, you're from that place, you've got to go.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Could I bum one of your cigarettes?--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --don't bother, I'll get it.

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: You've really got to go.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Just let me get a match.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: But I want you to know that I understand why you're afraid--a lot of good people down there at the Committee are afraid. I'm really sorry for what you're being put through.

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: All those articles you people write-- where do you find that stuff?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: We don't tell anyone that. Which is why you can talk to us. And if we can't verify what you say someplace else, we don't print it. That's another reason you can relax.

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: I'm relaxed--light your cigarette.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: You were Hugh Sloan's bookkeeper when he worked for Maurice Stans at Finance, and we were sort of wondering, did you go work for Stans immediately after Sloan quit or was there a time lapse?

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: I never worked for Sloan or Stans.

Speaker: bookkeeper's sister
Dialogue: Would you like some coffee or anything?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Can I sit down for a minute?

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: One minute but then--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --right, right, I've got to go.  Why did you lie just then?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: I was just curious--you don't do it well, so I wondered. Have you been threatened, if you told the truth, is that it?

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: ...No... never in so many words...

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: It's obvious you want to talk to someone--well, I'm someone.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: I'm not even going to put your name down. It's just so I can keep things straight.  Start with the money, why don't you?

Speaker: bookkeeper's sister
Dialogue: How do you like it?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Everything, please.

Speaker: bookkeeper's sister
Dialogue: I won't be a minute.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: The General Accounting report said there was a 350 thousand cash slush fund in Stans' safe. Did you know about that from the beginning?

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: There are too many people watching me--they know I know a lot--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --it was all in hundreds, wasn't it?

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: A lot of it was. I just thought it was sort of an all-purpose political fund--you know, for taking fat cats to dinner, things like that.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Could buy a lot of steaks, 350,000 dollars.

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: I can't be positive that it was used for the break-in but people sure are worried.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Which people?

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: The ones who could disburse the money.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Who were they?

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: There were a group of them--I think five, I don't know their names.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Sloan knew which five, didn't he?

Speaker: bookkeeper's sister
Dialogue: Here we are.

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: I don't want to say anymore.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --and you haven't finished telling me about the money--

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: --omigod, there was so much of it, six million came in one two-day period-- six million cash, we couldn't find enough places to put it. I thought it was all legal, I guess I did, til after the break-in, when I remembered Gordon got so much of it.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Gordon Liddy, you mean?

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: ...It's all so rotten... and getting worse... and all I care about is Hugh Sloan. His wife was going to leave him if he didn't stand up and do what was right. And he quit. He quit because he saw it and didn't want any part of it.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Think Sloan's being set up as a fall guy for John Mitchell? Sometimes it looks that way.

Speaker: bookkeeper
Dialogue: If you guys... if you guys could just get John Mitchell... that would be beautiful...

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: I  couldn't believe what she told me. Eight cups of coffee worth.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Go on, go on--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --we've got to find out who the five guys are--the five with access to the slush fund--they were aware of the break-in.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Then tomorrow's grand jury indictments will just be bullshit.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: It goes very high--we've got to find out where--

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: --we will--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --she was really paranoid, the bookkeeper.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: That happens to people.  OK, go on.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: How do you want to handle Sloan?

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: You mean, who's going to play the mean M.P. and who's going to be the nice one?  Whichever.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: He's another Ivy Leaguer so he'll probably expect you to be understanding--might surprise him if you're not.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: You want me to be the bastard.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: And I'll just shitkick in my usual way.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: To see Mr. Sloan.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: This must be a difficult time for the both of you.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: That's why we wanted to see your husband.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Maybe you could put in a good word.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: We've got another appointment tonight in this area--we'll just stop back later, all right?

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Think Sloan's back?  What's wrong?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Nothing--I just found out that Jeb Magruder from CREEP is a bigger bike freak than I am.  I never like it when the other guy's human...

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Mr. Sloan?

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: As you know, I haven't talked to the press.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: We were hoping that maybe now you could. We know why you left the Committee. We know you're not guilty of anything. But we know you know who is--

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: --look, come in. We'll have to be quiet--my wife's asleep.

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: I'd like to talk to you, I really would, but my lawyers say I shouldn't until after the Watergate trial.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: You handed out the money. Maybe there's a legitimate explanation for the way it was done--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --then again, maybe things are even worse than we've written--

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: --they're worse. That's why I quit.

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: Try and understand this. I'm a decent Republican. I believe in Richard Nixon. I worked in the White House four years--so did my wife. What happened on June 17 I don't think the President knew anything about. Some of his men I'm not so sure of.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Do you think the truth will come out at the trial?

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: That's another of the things I'm not so sure of.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Because people at the Committee were told to lie to the prosecutors?

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: We were never told flat out "Don't talk." But the message was clear.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: To cover up?

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: Well, they sure didn't ask us to come forward and tell the truth.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Does "they" mean the White House?

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: As opposed to the Committee? The Committee's not an independent operation. Everything is cleared with the White House. I don't think that the FBI or the prosecutors understand that.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: The report on the cash in Maurice Stans' safe, the three hundred fifty thousand, that's true?

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: No. It was closer to seven hundred thousand.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: And as treasurer, you could release those funds?

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: When so ordered.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: We're not sure we've got all the guys who could order you, but we know there were five.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Mitchell, Stans, Magruder, they're obvious--

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: --there had to be a White House overseer--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --Colson.

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: Colson's too smart to get directly involved with something like that.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Right?

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: I won't talk about the other two.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: But they both worked at the White House?

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: I will not talk about the other two.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Kalmbach--Nixon's personal lawyer.

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: I can't say anything, I'm sorry.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: One thing I'm not completely clear on--when you gave out the money to Liddy, how did that work?

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: Badly.  You don't realize how close all this came to staying undiscovered--I gave Liddy the Dahlberg check and he gave it to Barker who took it to Miami and deposited it.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: Then Barker withdrew the 25 thousand in hundred dollar bills and gave it back to Liddy who gave it back to me and I put it in the office safe which was crammed.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Go on.

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: Well, when Liddy came and asked for money for what turned out to be the break-in funds, I went to the safe and gave him--out of this whole fortune--I happened to give him the same hundreds he gave me--banks have to keep track of hundreds. If the money had been in fifties, or if I'd grabbed a different stack, there probably wouldn't have been any Watergate story.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Ordinarily, though, what was the procedure?

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: Routine--I'd just call John Mitchell over at the Justice Department and he'd say "go ahead, give out the money."

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: What happens when the baby comes?

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: We're moving.  I've been looking for a job but it's been... hard. My name's been in the papers too much. Sometimes I wonder if reporters understand how much pain they can inflict in just one sentence. I'm not thinking of myself. But my wife, my parents, it's been very rough on them.

Speaker: sloan
Dialogue: I wish I could put down on paper what it's like--you come to Washington because you believe in something, and then you get inside and you see how things actually work and you watch your ideals disintegrate.  The people inside, the people in the White House, they start to believe they can suspend the rules because they're fulfilling a mission. That becomes the only important thing-- the mission. It's so easy to lose perspective. We want to get out before we lose ours altogether.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Look--five men controlled that slush fund as CREEP--three of them we've got, Mitchell, Stans, Magruder, and we're pretty sure of Kalmbach.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: We'd like to wait til we have all five before we print it.

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: This is a daily paper, we'll explain it tomorrow.  You're certain on Mitchell?

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: He approved the payments to Liddy while he was still Attorney General--

Speaker: rosenfeld
Dialogue: --you got more than one source?--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --yes--

Speaker: simons
Dialogue: --has any of them got an ax?--

Speaker: rosenfeld
Dialogue: --political, personal, sexual, anything at all against Mitchell?--

Speaker: simons
Dialogue: --can we use their names?--

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: --goddamnit, when's somebody gonna go on the record on this story--

Speaker: rosenfeld
Dialogue: --who you got?--

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: --well, Sloan--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --and we got a guy in Justice--

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: --Deep Throat?--

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: --I saw him. He verifies.

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: OK.  Just be right, huh?

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: Leave plenty of room for his denial.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: John Mitchell, please.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Sir, this is Carl Bernstein of the Washington Post, and I'm sorry to bother you but we're running a story in tomorrow's paper that we thought you should have a chance to comment on.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: John N. Mitchell, while serving as US Attorney General, personally controlled a secret cash fund that--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --fund that was used to gather information against the Democrats--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --according to sources involved in the Watergate investigation. Beginning in the spring of 1971--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --almost a year before he left the Justice Department--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --to become President Nixon's campaign manager on March 1, Mitchell personally approved withdrawals from the fund--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Sir, I'd like to ask you a few--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Night.

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: He really made that remark about Mrs. Graham?  This is a family newspaper--cut the words "her tit" and run it.

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: Once when I was reporting, Lyndon Johnson's top guy gave me the word they were looking for a successor to J. Edgar Hoover. I wrote it and the day it appeared Johnson called a press conference and appointed Hoover head of the FBI for life... And when he was done, he turned to his top guy and the President said, "Call Ben Bradlee and tell him fuck you."  --I screwed up but I wasn't wrong.

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: You guys haven't been wrong yet, is that why you're scared shitless?  You should be...

Speaker: senator
Dialogue: Although I am a Republican, I would like to state in a pure bipartisan spirit that I feel only sadness that a once fine journal of record like the Post would have become merely the hysterical spokesman for the equally hysterical left wing of the Democratic Party--

Speaker: simons
Dialogue: Same kind of crap--

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: --all non-denial denials--we're dirty guys and they doubt we were ever virgins but they don't say the story is inaccurate.

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: What's a real denial?

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: If they ever start calling us goddamn liars--  --it's time to start circling the wagons.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: What do you think Mrs. Graham wants to see me for?

Speaker: simons
Dialogue: Maybe to fire you--since you two started on this story, the Post stock has dropped, what, 50 percent?  And the word is some Nixon people are challenging her TV licenses. I'm not saying she's going on relief, but I don't think it's unreasonable for her to want to meet you.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: You think she wants us to ease up on the story?

Speaker: simons
Dialogue: I don't know, but I don't think that's unreasonable either, do you?

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: --I'm Woodward.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: I think so.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: It may never come out.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Some Justice Department lawyers and an FBI man, and some people from the Committee to Re-Elect, yes ma'am.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: I couldn't say.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: It is.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: I would, if you really ever wanted to know.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: Nobody ever had too much.

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: I thought you guys were supposed to be working on this story--  --you think I like being aced out?

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --what?--

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: --The L.A. Times has a huge interview with Baldwin--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --the lookout in the Motor Inn?--  --he say anything we don't know?--

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: --just that a lot of reports were sent to CREEP, but he doesn't name who, not here anyway--

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: --it would have been nice to have had this, I sure would have liked to have had this--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --there's nothing new in it--

Speaker: bradlee
Dialogue: --it makes the break-in real--it's a major goddamn story--  --I'm not going to kick ass over this, but I'd like you to know I hate getting beat, I just hate it-- don't forget that I hate it--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: Goddamnit--

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: --shit--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --we gotta top the Times--

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: --I know, I know--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --if we could name the guys got the reports, we'd be ahead again--

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: --shit, who do we know?--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --I know a lawyer at Justice--

Speaker: woodward
Dialogue: --has he got an ax?--

Speaker: bernstein
Dialogue: --almost every source we've used has been Republican, this guy's a card- carrying Democrat.
